title: brexit latest theresa may brussels showdown donald tusk
story: The PM fronted up the EU boss and told him his outrageous comments were not helpful and caused widespread dismay in the UK.After talks with several EU leaders today she told reporters before heading back to Britain: Ive raised with President Tusk the language that he used yesterday, which is not helpful and caused widespread dismay in the United Kingdom.Mr Tusk sparked uproar by saying there was a place in hell reserved for Brexiteers who campaigned to leave without a plan.Now the PM said that talks will start to find a way to get this over the line and push her deal through the Commons.She vowed: My work is to deliver Brexit, to deliver it on time and I am going to be negotiating hard in the coming days to do just that.Its not going to be easy but crucially President Juncker and I have agreed that talks will now start to find a way through this.During the meeting, Mr Tusk risked anger by pressing Mrs May to accept an offer from Jeremy Corbyn to work together on a new soft Brexit plan.After todays summit, the PM will travel to Dublin tomorrow with Attorney General Geoffrey Cox for talks with Irish officials on a possible way forward.Shes understood to be targeting an EU-Africa summit in Egyptian resort Sharm El Sheikh later this month as a possible time to strike a final deal.On her way in to the EU headquarters the PMs convoy was interrupted by a Europhile protester, who threw himself in front of a car in an apparent bid to stop her.But she later got some better news as she convinced the EU to back down and hold more talks on the hated Northern Irish border.After a robust showdown with EU boss Jean Claude Juncker today, she managed to secure an extra three weeks of discussions on the UKs future relationship with the bloc.Mrs May insisted the UK must not be trapped in the Northern Ireland backstop and laid out a string of options to get out of the mess.The two leaders agreed that their teams should hold talks as to whether a way through can be found, a statement released from No said.Although Mr Juncker insisted the Withdrawal Agreement cannot be changed, he expressed his openness to edit the UKs future relationship with the EU to get to a deal quicker.No described the news as important progress today.But Mr Tusk warned that other EU leaders would have to agree to it too.The pair will meet again before the end of February to take stock, officials confirmed today, kicking the can for securing a deal even further down the road towards exit day in March.EU Parliament Antonio Tajani told reporters after separate talks with Mrs May that the EU would be more ambitious on our future relations, including looking at the Irish situation againthe UKs red lines change.But he warned: We are very concerned. Were weeks away from an economic and human catastrophe.The PM told the EUs Guy Verhofstadt that she wasnt seeking to rip up the backstop at all - which could risk the rage of Brexiteer MPs who demanded she find a whole new solution.But Mr Verhofstadt said they could upgrade the political declaration, making it more binding, more precise.And he admitted that leaving without a deal would hit the EU too - saying it would be a disaster on both sides of the channel.The Sun revealed last night that the PM is set to scrap the plan for Tory unity - the so-called Plan C - now EU leaders have shot it down.Allies say Mrs May knew beforehand that EU leaders will never accept it and wants to swtly move on over the weekend to pressing for legally binding changes to toughen up the current backstop.But the plans are still alive for now as they will be discussed on Monday with Michel Barnier, No confirmed this afternoon.Or instead of re-opening the deal, Brussels might allow a legally binding letter to make it clear that the hated backstop deal is only temporary, The Times reported today.This morning Jeremy Corbyn threatened to derail the talks by hinting that Labour could back a soft Brexit.He wrote to the PM laying out the conditions which his party would back a deal.Meanwhile, No last night played down the prospect of getting a breakthrough in time to put to MPs in next Thursday’s Commons votes.A senior Downing Street source said: “If the clouds clear then great, but realistically it’s not where we’re going.”The source added that the Government would have to put “something” down to vote on next Thursday but said he expects the “focus” will be on other amendments such as attempts to legislate against a no deal Brexit.Delaying the votes further will ramp up the pressure from Remainers to extend Article  to allow enough time to get all the legislation through the House of Commons in time.

title: labour lose votes brexit remainers desert corbyn
story: Jeremy Corbyns failure to back a second referendum could be far more damaging than the Iraq war, according to a leading trade union.It comes as young EU enthusiasts turn against Labour in protest against Mr Corbyns Brexit policy.The damning poll findings come in a document commissioned by the TSSA union, which asked YouGov to carry out a nationwide survey.The results, leaked to ITV News, suggest Labour would pick up votesit supported a second referendum on the EU.They concluded: There can be no disguising the sense of disappointment and disillusionment with Labourit fails to oppose Brexit and there is every indication that it will be far more damaging to the partys electoral fortunes than the Iraq war.Labour would especially lose the support of people below the age of , which could make this issue comparable to to impact the tuition fees and involvement in coalition had on Lib Dem support.The dossier suggests that nearly half of Labour voters may switch their vote to a new centrist partyit pledged to oppose Brexit.In a snap election where Labour backed Britain quitting the EU, it would lose an estimated  seats - leaving the party nowhere near power.Under Tony Blair, Labour shed more than million votes in the wake of the Iraq war.And the Lib Dems lost .million supporters during the coalition years amid fury at their support for university tuition fees.Today Mr Corbyn angered Remainer MPs by offering to work with Theresa May to pass a Brexit deal - instead of backing a second referendum.

title: brexit peoples vote disarray labour mp second referendum
story: Roger Godsf says it was only right that the public should have the “final say” on the Prime Minister’s deal when it is finalised.He will table an amendment to Theresa May’s withdrawal motion which is set to be debated on Valentine’s Day.The move is understood to have infuriated campaign chiefs at the People’s Vote – who fear there is no chance of a second referendum bid winning a majority in the House of Commons.Tory Remainers Sarah Wollaston and Philip Lee pulled a proposed second referendum amendment at the last minute last month under intense pressure from People’s Vote.Mr Godsf - whose Birmingham Hall Green voted to Remain in  - told The Sun: “The original decision was taken by the people.“So I think it’s only appropriate that there is a chance for Parliament to give it back to the people for them to make a decision on it.”Under his proposed amendment, the public will get to vote on three outcomes – the PM’s Brexit deal, No Deal or to Remain in the EU.Meanwhile Tory grandee Sir Edward Leigh today announced plans for a separate amendment designed to fix the problem of the backstop which has been the main stumbling block for Mrs Mays deal.The veteran MP said: If a get-out clause or specic end date can’t be agreed with the EU, as looks likely, we could use an instrument of international diplomacy called a conditional interpretative declaration to provide an end date.The device would allow the UK to declare legally that it cannot be bound by the backstop indefinitely - which would trap Britain in Europes customs union.Crucially, the EU wouldnt have to sign up to the declaration for it to be legally binding.And it wouldnt require rewriting the existing withdrawal agreement - which Brussels says is now impossible.

title: danny dyer right royal family flaw
story: A documentary that was as funny as it was surprising, and all the more so because the BBC did the right thing and played it absolutely straight.Genuine blue plaque television, in fact, that should never have been revisited or reformatted, not least because it would remind the Beeb that Danny’s wonderful everyman story had killed the whole WDYTYA franchise.So I’d been expecting this sucker punch, ever since its final credits rolled in .Danny Dyer’s Right Royal Family, on BBC. “A potty old adventure,” as his nibs described it, tracing Danny’s family line even further back, to Scandinavia’s King Rollo, his -times great grandfather, who I’d always assumed was a s children’s cartoon character, rather than a ninth-century Viking warrior.There were two episodes of it this time as well, which I know some of you thought were as funny as the original. Personally, I didn’t.What I hope we’re all agreed on, though, is the fact that Danny’s too busy playing Danny Dyer, the professional geezer, to be a good listener or natural TV historian.It’s an act that worked, of course, when he was wondering, “Eleanor of Aquitaine, was she a looker ” but didn’t serve him so well when presented with a longbow.“Long, innit ”The Beeb clocked this before production started, obviously, so had paired him up with dozens of head-patting historians and actors who got him to dress up as every kind of medieval t**t you can imagine. Like Mr Benn on crack, it was.Armour, codpieces, nappies, tights, doublet and hose, and a gigantic white smock, bleached with human urine, which had one grovelling “courtier” wondering: “Has all the p*** been washed out, my Lord King ”A good question.We didn’t actually get the answer, though, until part two, on Wednesday, when, after a brief detour round his ancestors, Louis IX of France, William the Conqueror and Henry II, viewers got to the nub of things, with Professor Chris Given-Wilson explaining the agonising death of Edward II: “By thrusting a hollow instrument, like the end of a trumpet, up his fundament.”“’Old on a minute,” said a rattled Danny. “He’s been stabbed  With a trumpet ”“Into his fundament.” Long pause.“Don’t tell me it’s up his a**e ”Right up it, Danny, with a red-hot poker. News which didn’t just do his “nut in”, it seemed to derail the entire documentary.They ran out of direct royal ancestors shortly afterwards as well, and the BBC adopted its stupid default setting in such circumstances. It turned Danny’s Right Royal Family into a dance and cookery show, complete with demonstrations of both, from medieval experts.It was about this time I also sussed out what was going on in the background, with all those winsome historians. An audition.The BBC was using it to find its new face of history, though why any of the blokes turned up is a mystery. Auntie’s already made it clear: “The days of white, middle-aged men explaining stuff are over.”Danny, on the other hand, can be tolerated, because he’s their new performing Cockney. A novelty act who can be dressed up and patronised so much he ended this one doing some weird medieval can-can, with his family, in front of his lost ancestral pile.A trumpet wasn’t quite shoved up his fundament as they danced, but the p*** had very much been washed out of him, my Lord King.GREAT TV lies and delusions of the month. “I think it’s going to be a really great show.” Cheryl Tweedy, The Greatest Dancer.“We do TV shows and we’re national treasures.” Jedward, Celebrity Coach Trip.“People will remember my name and I love that.” Some t**t off Ship- wrecked.IF you’re to take anything from the news experts have claimed Monday, January  was the most depressing day of the year, it’s probably the fact the experts clearly never sat through what happened eight days later, on Tuesday, January .Britain’s Top  Dogs Live: . All two-and-a-half yapping hours of it, on ITV, with a bad hangover, in the company of presenters Ben Fogle and Sara Cox.A test beyond personal endurance not because of the alcohol or dogs, who are a largely blameless lot, but the presence of their barmy owners, who attribute all sorts of superpowers to their dumb little mutts and blur the human animal relationship way beyond the point of reason and sometimes even good taste.Hits Radio DJ Gemma Atkinson, for instance, claimed: “I wouldn’t be where I am today without Norman”, her pet sproodle.Which is a hell of a guilt trip to pin on any dog.While Spandau Ballet’s Martin Kemp was seen, sitting alongside Popsie the poodle and his Wham! backing-singer we Shirlie, exclaiming: “I’ll say this for her,she does do a poo she goes into the spare bathroom.”The least you’d expect, frankly, after  years of marriage.The case study that really finished me off, though, was a dog dancing instructor called Joan Clark and her powder puff hounds, whose act, as described by Sara Cox, was: “All building up to the big finish. Can she pull it off  Joan points to the spot and it’s one, two, three pups between her legs.”CHANNEL ’s Pure is a comedy drama about a woman who suffers from the sixth sense of seeing naked people and is so tormented by her condition she screams: “F***ing stop. Make it stop.”So she can read minds as well.QUIZ show doughballs of the week. The Time It Takes, Joe Lycett: “Real Madrid play their home football matches in which Spanish city ”John: “Barcelona.”Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “Which month of the year was named after the Roman Emperor Augustus ”Jorge: “July.”Ben Shephard: “Hajduk Split are a football team from which eastern European country ”Jenner: “Japan.”And Joe Lycett: “In his song Le On Mars, David Bowie wonderedthere was le on which planet ”Amber: “Jupiter.” Andy Murray texting Good Morning Britain with the :am request: “Please stop discussing my genitals on national television.”Andrew Neil ripping all of Ken Livingstone’s socialist fantasies about Venezuela into tiny shreds, on This Week.And The Time It Takes answer contestant John gave to the question: “The metaphorical breaking of which body part brings good luck to an actor ” “Neck.” A thought that’s occurred to me every time I watch the Baftas.FAIR play, I thought, to Vagisan feminine itching cream and Jenny Eclair. They really seemed to have all the important ITV advertising bases covered.First thing in the morning they’re dropping regular hints about “bothersome vaginas” during Piers Morgan’s Good Morning Britain sht. Then there they were again, on Sunday night, directly before Gemma Collins skated at Dancing On Ice.Although, I say “skated,” you’d see marginally more movement from the Larsen C ice shelf in Antarctica than we got from Gemma on this week’s show.The heroic Matt Evers had to shove, heave, prod and generally wield her like a hypermarket shopping trolley, in fact, just to get Gemma turning on her axis.One very calculated burst of tears later, though, the mug punters had voted her through for yet another week and she’d parked her over-entitled backside on Piers Morgan’s sofa early yesterday morning.So where the hell was Vagisan feminine itching cream and Jenny Eclair when the occasion really called for them Asleep on the job, that’s where. Call yourself a “relief” GREAT Sporting Insights. Martin Keown: “Abramovich has spent £.billion at Cha. That’s £million per championship.”Jermaine Jenas: “The ball misses Trippier’s head by a second.”John Inverdale: “Warren Gatland began his reign  years ago to the day, tomorrow.”And Paul Merson: “Petr Cech was a great shop spotter.”Sent in by Tom Baxter, Denny, Stirlingshire. Picture research Jimbo.RANDOM TV irritations: The widespread but mistaken belief that “you just can’t have too much Romesh Ranganathan”.The Voice UK audience member who shouted: “Olly, I think you should sing.” Jonathan Davies’ complete inability to keep his Welsh bias out of the rugby commentary box.ITV’s Small Fortune already looking like the worst game show of the year.  And catchphrase-chasing hosts Alesha Dixon and Jordan Banjo declaring, “Things are getting really seri-arse”, on The Greatest Dancer, just at the point things were getting even more tedi-arse.TV OBSERVATION round. Who said the following last week “It looks like it’s dragging its legs on the floor, doing a hip wiggle. But it’s actually scent-marking with its anal glands, on the side of a track, on the side of a road, anywhere a passing male might snf it.”A Iolo Williams on Winterwatch’s pine marten B Sam Matterface on Dancing On Ice’s Gemma Collins Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: NewsGet rid of your dog or get out: Man homeless after refusing to give up his petWe met Shane Hart at Rotherham Soup Kitchen during the Daily Mirrors investigation into rough sleeping - and now there is good news for him and his dog KimmyShareCommentsByLucy Thornton:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video mirroronthestreet-campaign-kimmy-dog-rough-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email“Not everyone is as lucky as we are.” The simple truth given by a mum to her four-year-old when he asked her why there was a man huddled, shivering in a shop doorway this week. But that man, Shane Hart, did have a bit of luck that night, as caring Nicole White and her family took him and his beloved dog Kimmy to Rotherham Soup Kitchen. It was a helping hand that has now seen Shane, , rescued from le on the streets. He had been kicked out of his flat in the South Yorkshire town for having Kimmy, who he’d rescued, and had been living in nearby Kimberworth Park.  “I’d been feeling so guilty, I was scared I was hurting Kimmy because it was so cold,” he said. She hadn’t asked for all this. “It was so cold the condensation in the tent turned into icicles and the zip was frozen shut. It even hurt to breathe in.”  It was love at first sight five months ago for Shane when he spotted Kimmy, a runt of the litter who’d been rejected by its mum and left shivering in a cage. He bottle fed the Whippet-cross, and when forced to leave his “no-dogs” flat, named her Kimmy after the park they were living in.  “I was suffering from depression but Kimmy saved my le. Twice, she saved my le,” he said. “She’s all I’ve got and makes me smile every day. She’s all I live for.” Ten days ago someone slashed Shane’s tent and trashed his belongings. Since then he’s been spending hours every day begging, once making pound after four hours, which he immediately spent on a dog coat for Kimmy.Another day he collected just enough to buy a pasty. Not for himself, for Kimmy.After Nicole, , husband Mitchell, , and their son Dylan drove him to the soup kitchens he was clearly stunned, and wept as he was handed hot food, sleeping bags and dog biscuits. As the Street Paws charity treated Kimmy to worm and flea treatment and inoculations, he looks at his bag of gts, hugs his pet and cries again, saying: “Oh wow. I don’t believe this, it’s too much all this” The pair clearly have an incredible bond, as Kimmy kisses his tears away.  Shane has now been given accommodation by Rotherham Borough Council, whose Assistant Director of Housing, Tom Bell, said: “The council is funding temporary accommodation for this gentleman and his dog while we work with him to find a permanent home.”  Street Paws founder, Michelle Southern, who has just opened their st outreach, says only  per cent of hostels accept dogs.She said the rough sleepers’ dogs they see are incredibly well looked after.“I’ve known people to be sat in an ambulance but refuse treatment because they are worried about what is going to happen to their dog,” she said.

title: people tissue thin slice away
story: NewsPeople are a tissue thin slice away from disaster: Homeless mans warning to us allWe spoke to homeless people at Encompass Southwest in Barnstaple, Devon, as part of our Mirror On The Street investigation into rough sleepingShareByAdam Aspinall:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsRichards relationship breakdown led him to ruin and he has never quite recovered "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHomelessness can strike anyone, at anytime. That was the message The Daily Mirror learned on a visit to a breakfast club for rough sleepers this week. Never more was this in evidence then -year-old Richard. Once a respected news reporter on a local paper it seemed he had the world at his feet. But like so many homeless people a relationship breakdown led him to ruin and he has never quite recovered. He has lived on and off the streets ever since. He said: “People are a tissue thin slice away from disaster, they just don’t think about it.” Richard, who along with others in this article did not wish to give his full name, was just one of many vulnerable adults and young people who wandered in and out of the breakfast club organised by independent homeless charity Encompass Southwest, based in Barnstaple, Devon.  The charity has gone from a tiny soup kitchen in  to employing  full and part-time members of staff who provide a range of service to tough sleepers in North Devon from advice, to support services and housing. One of the many services Encompass offer rough sleepers is a popular breakfast club every Tuesday morning in the spare room of a local radio station. Manned by staff and volunteers at least  rough sleepers came and went from am until noon all with ying stories to tell but all just thankful for a warm breakfast. The age range was shocking, the youngest was  and the eldest , from a wide iety of walks of le. Frightened Will, , revealed he was kicked out of his house by his parents and has slept rough for five months. He says there are lots of people who try to take advantage of him so admitted he has carried a weapon in the past to feel safe. He said: “It’s a nightmare out there, people will abuse youthey can so you have to be wary, I’m just focusing on getting out of this situation the best way I can.”  Gavin, , said he used to be able earn as much pound a day when he ran his own tiling business but a relationship break-up saw him lose everything. He now sleeps in a park which he describes as “scary”. He said people need to understand that “homelessness can happen to anyone, at anytime.” Amongst the many cheerful volunteers was humble AE nurse Sarah Gabe, . She volunteers at the breakfast club every week and admitted it took some time to win the rough sleeper’s trust but now she can use of her medical skills to treat them directly.  She said: “It took about six months for them to trust me to the point where they now come to me with problems. “It is mainly simple things like foot care and listening to their chests but when you are sleeping rough small things can become big problems so it is great that I can see them directly and help them where I can.”  One rough sleeper at the breakfast club who has definitely benefited from Encompass’s hands-on approach is -year-old Paul. Originally from London he explained he drted out to Devon because it was “safer” but a mixture of drink and drug problems have kept him on the streets ever since. He is what homelessness experts describe as ‘entrenched’ and in years gone by may never have got the help he required and could easily have died on the streets. But Encompass have adopted a new scheme called Housing First which started in the USA in the s and has since spread to Europe. The idea behind the approach is to give entrenched rough sleepers like Paul some control over where they live and how rather then assigning them places to live under strict rules and regulations. The British Government has recently invested poundm in Housing First pilot projects across the country. While Encompass have not received any of that money they have copied the approach and slowly persuaded Paul to live in his own flat after years on the streets. According to his Encompass support worker like Becky Fausset, , who has been working with rough sleepers for over  years, Paul’s new flat could very well be the dference between le and death. She said: “These are people that another winter and they could be dead and that is not being dramatic, so being able to get them into accommodation is very rewarding. “Housing First is dficult but incredibly positive, the dficulty is finding the properties, but so far it seems to be working. “People come to pretty places like Barnstaple and North Devon and don’t realise what is really going on and how many people are really struggling.” Paul finally moved in this week but when The Mirror visited the flat with him on Monday for the first time he was overwhelmed.  He said: “I can’t believe it, I feel like a real person again, someone that’s worth something, this is everything and I’m not going to let it go.” According to the latest research from the respected IPPR think-tank there was  per cent rise in rough sleeping in rural areas from  in  to  in . Butyou speak to people working on the front line of this problem they will tell you privately the true figures are likely to be much higher because the issue is so dficult to record. The Daily Mirror spent two days there with the dedicated staff of one homeless charity this week in a bid to highlight this worrying trend. We were hosted by the indomitable Claire Fisher, the CEO of Encompass.  Fighting her own personal battle against cancer Claire thinks nothing of manning the front lines each day and can be seen walking the streets and dishing out food to rough sleepers with her fellow colleagues. She explained how people could not believe areas like North Devon even had a homeless problem associating it with sunny holidays and second homes.  She said: “Believe it or not this is considered a deprived area round here which is really dficult to comprehend when you think of the beaches and the summer holidays but people are missing the reality of what le is like for people who live here year round. “We have a perfect storm here of a lack of industry, low paying jobs, zero hour contracts and a very low stock of social housing meaning people cannot afford to buy. “House prices are four times the average wage down here so they are reliant on the private rented sector and that is not always reliable.” She also pointed out how some rough sleepers actively choose to live in the countryside leaving them invisible to outside support. She said: “We do have people that choose to rough sleep in rural areas, purely because it is quieter, the risks are lower and they are not as open to abuse. Some of them can be very self sufficient. “I think a lot of the resources are focused on cities because it so visual there butyou come down here on holiday you don’t see it as much but actually we really have high numbers here and then others we are not aware of – we rely heavily on people like the Forestry Commission and farmers for tips about where people have set-up shop. “People need to realise that rural homelessness is happening, you may not see it, but it is all around you.”

story: NewsBrexit: Glaring Theresa May kicks vote back as far as MARCH after robust Brussels talksIt could be weeks before glaring Theresa May goes to Brussels again after EU chief Jean-Claude Juncker rebuffed her bid to reopen talks on the -page orce dealShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video theresa-may-refuses-to-smile-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailStony-faced Theresa May kicked MPs Brexit vote back as far as MARCH today after struggling through robust talks with Brussels. EU chief Jean-Claude Juncker rebuffed her bid to reopen talks on the -page Brexit deal - including a controversial backstop. So the pair have now arranged further talks - but only before the end of February. And questioned today, a No spokeswoman refused to rule out putting a revised deal to MPs in March - which would be just weeks before the UK leaves the EU on March .   Instead the No spokeswoman said: Were working to bring it back as soon as possible. Mrs May, whose convoy was ambushed by anti-Brexit protester, pointedly did not raise a smile as she arrived and shook hands with Mr Juncker at EU headquarters.  She also held talks with EU Parliament chiefs Guy Verhofstadt and Antonio Tajani, and EU Council President Donald Tusk - who said yesterday there was a special place in hell for Tory Brexiteers. She confronted Tusk over his hell remark, telling reporters it caused widespread dismay.But despite just  days being left to Brexit, it is believed Mrs May put forward no specic solutions today to break the deadlock. She told Mr Juncker she will continue to seek legally binding changes to the -page Brexit deal. Yet Mr Juncker made clear that the EU will not reopen talks on the deal.  Mrs May has promised MPs a general vote next Thursday  February which will let them direct the way forward. But this is not the same as a meaningful vote to pass or defeat her Brexit plan, with legal effect. Now, with talks on deadlock, there are fears that meaningful vote will only be held weeks before the UK leaves the EU.   One government source told the Mirror they feared the clock ticking down as late as March  before a deal is struck. And a joint statement issued by Mrs May and Mr Juncker today did not commit to a firm timeframe. The discussion was robust but constructive, the statement said. Despite the challenges, the two leaders agreed that their teams should hold talks as to whether a way through can be found that would gain the broadest possible support in the UK Parliament and respect the guidelines agreed by the European Council.  The Prime Minister and the President will meet again before the end of February to take stock of these discussions. BrexitSecretary Stephen Barclay and EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier will also meet next Monday. The statement confirmed Mrs May set out MPs demands for a legally binding change to the backstop - an insurance clause that would keep the UK trapped under EU customs rules. Yet Mr Juncker underlined that the EU will not reopen the Withdrawal Agreement, which contains the backstop. Instead he is only willing to negotiate the separate political declaration, which spells out future trade. In a glimmer of hope, EU Parliament Brexit co-ordinator Guy Verhofstadt said the political declaration could be upgraded to make it more binding.  He told reporters: Our proposal is to try to solve the problem in the political declaration. We are open as Parliament from Day One to upgrade this political declaration to make this political declaration more binding, more precise. Also on the issue of the backstop, explaining and saying very clearly that this is an insurance, not more than that. Mr Verhofstadt added that Mrs May assured him there is no question to remove a backstop. Meanwhile Jeremy Corbyn has offered Theresa May a way out of the mess.  Labours leader vowed to back her deal -she guarantees a full customs union with the EU. But Mrs May has already said she does not want a customs union, meaning the offer is unlikely to be taken up. And the big offer has enraged some Labour MPs who want Mr Corbyn to back a second referendum instead. Shadow Brexit Secretary Keir Starmer was forced to intervene after a backlash, insisting the Labour leaders letter did not take the prospect of a public vote off the table.

title: alfie lamb ex tory ministers
story: NewsAlfie Lamb: Boyfriends annoyed words as he crushed tot to death with car seatStephen Waterson, from Croydon, south London, said he would "not be told what to do by a three-year-old", a court heard todayShareByEmily PenninkSophie Evans:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsToddler Alfie Lamb was crushed to death with a car seat, the Old Bailey has heard "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn ex-Tory ministers son made annoyed remarks as he crushed his girlfriends toddler to death with his car seat, a court has heard. Nightclub worker Stephen Waterson, , said he would not be told what to do by a three-year-old, Londons Old Bailey was told. It is alleged that Waterson became annoyed at the cries of his partners son, Alfie Lamb, and twice pushed his chair into him. The incident occurred during a journey in his Audi convertible back to his home in Croydon, south London, in February last year. Waterson, son of former government minister Nigel Waterson, has denied Alfies manslaughter, along with his girlfriend Adrian Hoare. Hoare, , is alleged to have failed to prevent the tragedy.  Giving evidence in court, Hoare said her son was tired and moaning after a shopping trip to Sutton, south London, on February , . On the journey home, there were six people in Watersons Audi, including two children in the rear footwell. Hoare, who was in the back seat with Alfie, said the tot was irritable and tired and made it known he was uncomfortable. When Waterson first moved his front seat back, the youngster called out Mummy but was still moving about, jurors heard. Hoare asked him to go forward again, the court was told.  The hairdresser said: When he first moved the chair back Alfie was still moving about and had room so I did not think there was a problem. He was just calling Mummy. It obviously made Alfie uncomfortable with the amount of space he did have. Stephen got annoyed with him. He shouted at Alfie and told him to shut up. It made him jump when Stephen shouted at him and he started to cry more. Alfie had got louder when he got scared at Stephen shouting and obviously Stephen being annoyed was quite loud as well. After he said that he did not have room for his legs, he made another comment along the lines he was not being told what to do by a three-year-old because we asked for the chair to be moved, and he moved his chair back again.  The defendant said she never thought Alfie was in danger or in trouble and assumed when he stopped crying and went quiet that he had fallen asleep. On arriving at Watersons address in Adams Way, Alfie went all floppy, jurors heard. Hoare said: Everybody thought he was playing to start with. He was just all floppy, but hes done it before when he has not wanted to do something. He would muck about and not respond. After paramedics were called, Waterson left the scene, jurors heard. The court has been told that the defendants went on to lie to authorities about what happened.  Hoare, originally from Gravesend, Kent, denies manslaughter, child cruelty and common assault on Emily Williams, who was also in the car. Waterson has pleaded not guilty to manslaughter and intimidation of the driver Marcus Lamb. The couple and Williams have pleaded guilty to conspiring to pervert the course of justice by making  statements to police.

title: amber peats natural dad found
story: NewsAmber Peats natural dad found out she was missing from Facebook postAdrian Cook discovered his -year-old daughter Amber Peat had vanished and immediately called the number on her missing persons posterShareByTom DavidsonOnline Reporter:,  FEB NewsAmber Peat, , from Mansfield "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe natural father of schoolgirl Amber Peat has told the inquest into her death he was subjected to vile abuse by her stepdad after he discovered his daughter had gone missing via Facebook. Adrian Cook said he tried to contact Amber’s mum, Kelly Peat, following the -year-old’s disappearance. He hadn’t seen her for more than two years after the family moved home without telling him. But when Mr Cook discovered Amber had vanished on social media and called a number on her missing persons poster, he claimed he got hold of stepdad Danny Peat who he said told him: “She is not your f ***ing daughter. She wants nothing to do with you. You are nothing but a sperm donor.”  Amber stormed out of her home in Mansfield, Nottinghamshire, in May  after being ordered to clean out a cool box. She was found hanged in a hedgerow three days later. An inquest into her death has heard claims the teenagers treatment at home might amount to emotional abuse and that she was subjected to a series of draconian punishments – including being told to wash every pot in the kitchen - for ‘undesirable behaviour’. Mr Cook gave evidence to the Nottingham hearing on its ninth day after deciding to attend in person. It was originally only intended a statement from him would be read. He told coroner Laurinda Bower how he and Kelly met around  and had two children before splitting on Christmas Eve , when he moved out of the family home in Derbyshire.  Mr Cook said he last saw his children in early , when Amber was , and took them for a meal in a pub. He claimed she was ‘happy and cheerful’ – until he said he had to take her home. Asked by Ms Bower why that was the final time he saw them, Mr Cook replied: “My shts were all over the place. “I tried to ring Kelly and said I would be off this week, and Kelly said I could not see them at the drop of a hat. “I would ring and it would be, ‘we are going here’, or ‘we are going there’. “Every time I phoned her it would be ‘inconvenient’. There would be ‘family business’ to see to, or ‘we are taking them here, or there’.  “The last time was a heated discussion. It was getting to the point where you are beaten down by it. I wanted to see the children.” Mr Cook said that during their last conversation, Kelly told him: “You just can’t see them when you want to.” The inquest heard he considered talking to a solicitor, but didn’t feel he ‘had a leg to stand on’. At some point around March , he went to their home – but found it was empty. Mr Cook said: “I went to a friends’ house on the estate, but they said that one morning they woke up and they had upped and gone. I had no idea where they’d gone.”  He added the next contact he had with the Peats was on the day after Amber disappeared. Mr Cook told the hearing: “I found out in Facebook so I tried to contact Kelly with the number off the missing person posters. “I got vile abuse off Danny – ‘she is not your f ** daughter, she wants nothing to do with you, you are nothing but a sperm donor. “I phoned back again and spoke to Danny’s mum. I didn’t get much information. I was in deep shock about it.” He added he didn’t know about any issues surrounding his daughter that the inquest had heard about, including her running away from home previously and problems at school. Mr Cook’s mum Jenner Lancaster – Amber’s grandmother – then gave evidence. She described her granddaughter as a ‘lovely, sweet, lovable child’ who ‘liked to cuddle and play silly girly things like dressing up, and with her make-up bag’. Mrs Lancaster said she saw Amber ‘quite frequently’ when she was young – but when her son and Kelly split up she only saw her ‘two or three’ times before her death.  One of the occasions was Valentines’ Day in , when Danny wanted to cook Kelly a ‘romantic meal’ and the children went to stay with her for the weekend. But Mrs Lancaster said Amber was ‘weepy’ because she had overheard a conversation between Kelly and her mum, Dianne Gillibrand, in which they had said she ‘wouldn’t want them.’ Mrs Lancaster said: “I told them I would always want them. How can you not want two little children like that, that give you so much pleasure  “It struck me as odd.” Mrs Lancaster next saw the young siblings on Mother’s Day , but they couldn’t stop for long because Kelly was waiting in her car outside. She gave them a pair of charm bracelets, and expected to see them again before she went into hospital that April for a knee operation – but never did. She told the hearing: “I got a message from Kelly to say they loved the bracelets, and that was it. “I bought them Easter eggs and sent a message to seethey would be coming for them. And I wanted to get Amber a birthday present because I was going in hospital. But the messagewas, ‘don’t know, not sure’. That was it.” Mrs Lancaster added that she went to the family home in a bid to see them – but found they had moved. When she contacted Kelly to ask for the new address – only to be told: “I am not comfortable with you having it.” She said: “I thought, ‘this is really strange’, but that is the way it was.”  Mrs Lancaster found out Amber had gone missing through her sister, and ‘panicked’. She said she had no concerns about her granddaughter’s behaviour, and what had happened ‘came as a shock’. Referring to the Peats, she said: “They trust you with their kids and then stop you seeing them, and the next thing you know she is missing. “It’s horrible, it really is horrible. “I phoned Kelly’s number and Danny answered, and I said, ‘where is my granddaughter ’ I said I need to speak to Kelly. He said, ‘she does not want anything to do with that side of the family.’ So what do you do ” Pausing to wipe away tears, Mrs Lancaster added: “When shepassed away, I did not even get to see her at the undertakers. They had to contact Kelly. “I did not realise until that point just how cruel she could be. And it is cruel. That is how it is.” The inquest continues.

title: beautiful mum infectious laugh found
story: NewsBeautul mum with an infectious laugh found dead at home aged just Ellie Majors dad said his daughter did not mean to take her own le after she was found with a lethal cocktail of drugs in her systemShareByTom Kershaw:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsEllie was found dead at home "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe heartbroken family of a beautul mum with an infectious laugh have paid tribute after she was found dead at her home.Ellie Major, , died with a lethal cocktail of prescription drugs in her system.Ms Majors dad said she did not mean to take her own le at her home in Hessle, Hull Live reports.Her family described her as a brilliant mum to her son, aged three. Paying tribute, Ms Majors sister, Emily Major, , said: You can see from the pictures how beautul and stunning my sister was. She was a loving and caring parent and a brilliant mother to her three-year-old son. She had a really distinctive and infectious laugh. At the inquest, coroner Professor Paul Marks said the evidence showed Ms Majors death was an accident.   Ms Majors father, Mark David Major, said she had been looking forward to spending time on two booked holidays. He said: I think it was just an accident. She was just wanting to get her high. Ellie did not mean to take her own le and under estimated the strength of her tablets.The mum-of-one had been diagnosed with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, a type of arthritis effecting her joints, when she was aged  and was prescribed painkillers to deal with the pain.An inquest into her death atHull Coroners Courtheard Ms Major had attempted to end her own le by overdosing on drugs in March , which resulted in her losing custody over her son. But it had taken six months for her to be assessed by mental health experts because she was not a high risk - a decision which her family said had contributed to her poor mental health.   Ms Majors social worker told the hearing that the young mum had been “at the bottom of her list” because she was at a low medium risk. She told the hearing through tears: When I found out about Ellie’s death I was following up an appointment with her. I never accepted it, and that is what has thrown me so much. When I spoke with Ellie, she reassured me that her previous attempt to take her own le was impulsive and she was very remourseful. But Ms Majors heartbroken mother Marie Mitchell, , said it was beyond her she had been deemed a low risk. She said: How they can say there is not an urgent risk for a mum who tried to take her own le is beyond me - and her first assessment only happened six months later. Service manager at the Humber NHS Trust Jo Kent had put together a report and said no lessons had been learnt since Ellie’s tragic death.  Workers at the mental health teams said that Ellie had not attended planned meetings. The family also demanded answers over why Ellie was still being given eight dferent types of medication, despite her using the drugs to take her own le previously. Mr Major said he grew concerned about his daughter when he did not receive a WhatsApp message from her. She was found dead in her home in Hessle on August , . Police Officer John Norcross found “boxes and bags of prescription drugs” across the property. PC Norcross told the hearing: There was no evidence of third party involvement or anything suspicious.  Dr Ian Richmond, consultant histopathologist, said that the medical cause of death was multiple drug toxicity. Concluding the inquest as an open conclusion, coroner Professor Paul Marks said the evidence showed Ms Majors death was an accident. He said: The evidence heard today could make me believe up to the civil standard of proof, that I am persuaded by her fathers communication, this is probably an accident. The family said they would be looking to lodge a complaint with the NHS and take things further. Her heartbroken mother Marie said: It is better than what we were expecting, but we still have a lot of unanswered questions which we couldnt ask because the GP didnt have Ellies notes in front of him. story: NewsDad who plotted Home Bargains acid attack on son, , describes arrest shockThe dad, , who cannot be named for legal reasons, said the first he knew of the acid attack at Home Bargains in Worcester is when he was arrestedShareByRichard Vernalls:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video horror-moment-young-boy-doused-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man accused of plotting an acid attack on his three-year-old son has told a jury he was never involved and was shocked to be arrested. The boy suffered serious burns to his face and arm at the Home Bargains store in Worcester on July  last year, during a parental custody dispute. His -year-old father, who cannot be identied for legal reasons, is charged with conspiring to unlawfully or maliciously cast or throw sulphuric acid on or at the boy between June  and July , with intent to burn, maim, disfigure or disable the minor, or do grievous bodily harm. A trial jury at Worcester Crown Court has already been shown dramatic CCTV allegedly of the moment of the attack, and heard how the injured child screamed I hurt after being struck.  Giving evidence in his defence for the first time on Thursday, the father was asked: In July last year, did you arrange for acid to be thrown at your son  The father, standing in the witness box wearing a white shirt and jeans and speaking through a Dari interpreter, said: No, never. He told his barrister, Phil Bradley QC, he only found out about the attack when he was arrested at his Wolverhampton home. Asked about his feelings on being detained, he told the jury: I was very shocked. Mr Bradley asked: Had you any idea that little boy was going to be attacked   The father replied no and denied knowing anyone might have been following his son with acid. He also denied telling his we she had humiliated him after the couple split on a previous occasion in , resulting in her leaving the family home with the children. He was then asked about an allegation his we repeated to jurors during her evidence, when she claimed he had spoken to an imam about killing her and the children because she had left him. Askedhe had ever asked such a question, he replied: No, I cannot even think of that. The father, originally from Afghanistan, is on trial alongside Adam Cech, , of Farnham Road, Birmingham Jan Dudi, , of Cranbrook Road, Birmingham Norbert Pulko, , of Sutherland Road, London Martina Badiova, , of Newcombe Road, Handsworth, Birmingham Saied Hussini, , of Wrottesley Road, London and Jabar Paktia, , of Newhampton Road, Wolverhampton.  They all deny the same charge. When the clip from a Home Bargains shop camera was played to jurors last week, the boys father held a tissue to his face. Opening the prosecution case, Jonathan Rees QC said the boys mother had driven to the store with her children at about pm to buy a party gt. CCTV, which has been played in court, showed her being followed by a silver Vauxhall Vectra, allegedly containing Cech, Dudi and Pulko. At .pm she and the children went inside the store, followed shortly after by three men, with shop CCTV apparently showing Cech approaching the victim.  The victim was standing with his sibling near a display of toy footballs when a man in a white T-shirt, identied without dispute in court as Cech, walked past the victim with his arm extended and an object in his hand. As Cech exited the frame, the victim could be seen looking quickly back towards him before running to his mother nearby. Mr Rees told jurors: What you have just seen is that person in a white T-shirt - you can just catch the moment where the arm is extended. That really is the hub of this case. That is the acid attack. It is over in a split second. The boy suffered a cm burn to his left forearm, and a cm burn on his forehead, which needed specialist hospital treatment. The Crown has also claimed that Hussini, Pulko and Badiova were involved in an aborted attempt near a school eight days before the shop attack.  Jurors have also been shown what the prosecution described as some stickers being sent with mots and images, from the victims father to Paktia, later on the evening after the attack, including one which read Nailed It!The first showed a cartoon image of what appeared to be a deer, leaning over and comforting a tearful fox. Mr Rees said: At .pm, hesends Paktia a sticker. One animal comforting a fox which has its head in its hands.  And then, the second is sent, a minute after that first one, again to Paktia. It is a sticker which features a young lady in it with the mot Nailed It!. Jurors have been told by the prosecution that Cech and Pulkos mobile phones had both been manually reset to factory settings before being seized by police. The trial continues.

title: emiliano salas dog waiting him
story: NewsEmiliano Salas dog waiting for him broke hearts - heres other pooches devotion to dead ownersThe Premier League stars dog, Nala, has been pictured waiting patiently for her owner to ShareCommentsByLouise Elliott:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsSalas dog, Nala, waits patiently for hisfollowing the plane crash"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email The tragic image of Emiliano Sala s dog waiting for him tohas broken hearts around the world. Sala went missing aboard a piper malibu aircraft over the English Channel on January  shortly after signing for Cardf in a club-record, poundmillion deal.Both the wreckage and a body have since been discovered but it has not yet been identied.Salas devastated sister, Romina, posted a b[icture of his beloved dog , Nala, on Facebook .It shows the pooch, looking out of the window and staring into the distance - waiting for his master to .   Romina captioned the image: Nala is waiting for you, too. Sala had a very close relationship with his dog, with Nala reportedly one of the reasons the star ed to France. It is understood the Argentinian had taken Nala to kennels and was in the process of moving her to Wales to live with him. She loved to chase animals and to go on long walks with the Premier Legue star. If Salas familys worst fears are confirmed, the footballers sister has vowed to look after Nala.   But devoted Labrador Nala is not the only dog to show heartbreaking devotion to her owner after theyve passed away. Many dogs have waited patiently, forever, for their masters to . Their devotion, loyalty and service dont end long after their owners have gone. Greyfriars Bobby is arguably the most famous of these devoted dogs.  The terrier belonged to John Gray, who worked in for Edinburgh City Police as a night watchman. Bobby was so devastated he spent the next  years sitting on Grays grave until he too died in . There is now a statue of Bobby on the corner of Edinburghs Candlemakers Row and George IV bridge. Police officer and his loyal pal  Constable David Ross, a Canadian mounted police officer, was killed in the line of duty in . His devoted service dog and pooch partner, Danny, was heartbroken that his master was gone. Danny could be heard whimpering throughout Con Rosss funeral and even snfed the stetson of his officer pal. Presidential grief  President George Bushs labrador service dog was heartbroken at his death. Sully was pictured resting beside his coffin in a moving tribute to his former master. The dog even travelled with President Bushs casket when it was transported on Air Force One from Texas to Washington. Even floods wont stop this dog  After this dogs owner was killed in the floods in Brazil, the pooch refused to leave his graveside. Leao coldnt bare leaving Cristina Maria Cesario Sanatnas side, even in death. Film star pooch  Hidesaburo Ueno was killed in an accident at work in . For nine years his loyal dog Hachiko, an Akita, waited for his master toat Tokyo train station. His devotion to his human best friends was turned into a film by Richard Gere. Guest of honour  Not even death could break the powerful bond between loyal dog Hawkeye and his handler, navy SEAL Jon Tumilson. The cherished black labrador led Tumilsons family into the funeral in Iowa in . Petty Officer Tumilson was one of  SEALS killed when their Chinook helicopter was shot down by Afghan insurgents. Determined dog  Border collie Spot trekked four miles, crossing a main road, canal and rail line, to find the grave of owner Denis Goodier in Macclesfield, Cheshire. story: NewsHaunting letter of Brit, , shared moments before he ended le in wes arms at DignitasGeoff Whaley, , said his final weeks were "blighted" by police who questioned his we Ann, , about her involvement and in a final letter published as he ended his le, he urged MPs to change the law on assisted suicideShareCommentsByAmber Hicks:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror tv tv-news video geoff-whaley-ending-le-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAt am this morning Geoff Whaley died in his wes arms at a Dignatis clinic after sipping a cup of water laced with lethal drugs. The moment had been a long time coming for Mr Whaley who travelled from his home in Chalfont St Peter in Buckinghamshire to the facility in Switzerland with we Ann, adopted children Alix and Dominic, and some close friends. But before the -year-old took his last breath surrounded by his loved ones, there was one final thing he needed to do - publish a haunting letter he hoped would be his legacy.He titled it: By the time you read this, I will be dead and addressed it to all Members of Parliament urging them to change the law surrounding assisted suicide .  No family should ever have to endure the torment we have undergone in recent weeks, the retired accountant wrote. But it will be easier to bear knowing that by sharing it we can contribute to future change. Mr Whaley, a grandfather-of-four, was diagnosed with Motor Neurone Disease, an incurable, terminal illness, in . As the years passed he lost the use of his limbs. His ability to speak, swallow and breath also began to rapidly deteriorate. However, he knew the worst was still to come which is why he chose to die in Switzerland rather than face immense suffering in the end stages of the devastating condition.He admitted to the BBC : This is one of the illnesses you wouldnt wish on your worst enemy.  But not only was Mr Whaley crippled by the disease in his final weeks, he says he suffered immense anguish at the hands of police and social services who were tipped off about Mr Whaleys plans. Mrs Whaley, , found herself being interviewed under caution by Thames Valley Police. And Mr Whaley said the added stress of police involvement had destroyed everything we had done to prepare ourselves. He wrote: I was saying my final goodbyes and preparing myself for the end, the final, biggest bomb dropped and I could no longer keep it together.   This bomb was in fact an anonymous phone call to social services who informed the police of my plans to go to Switzerland. Within hours Ann and I were facing a criminal investigation. The thought that I might not make it to Switzerland, or that,I did, Ann might be facing  years in jail for helping me, was almost too much to bear. Mrs Whaley, , who supported her husbands decision, told the BBC it was the first time in their  years of marriage that she had ever seen her husband cry. He said everything that Ive worked for to protect you has all been blown apart by this anonymous phone call, she said.   I wasnt frightened because I didnt feel like Id done anything wrong. I wasnt ashamed. I was cross. There was a policewoman and a detective sergeant and they were clearly not expecting to find a non-abusive situation because they were very embarrassed about the whole thing. Helping someone commit suicide is punishable by up to  years in prison. Mrs Whaley booked the flights to Switzerland and a hotel because her husband could no longer use his hands. It was so ridiculous to put us through this when he is in the final few days of le, she said. Police have since dropped the case, but the couple want to see the law changed to allow assisted dying in some circumstances.  They believe the law can be written to ensure vulnerable people are still protected from abuse. Mrs Whaley admitted: I just want him to be here, but I know what he has chosen to do is the right thing for him.I wouldnt put an animal through what he would go throughhe went to the end. At least three Britons have faced a police investigation after ing from a loved ones assisted death at a Dignitas clinic, the Times reported, although no-one has been prosecuted. When askedhe is concerned about the consequences his we could face, Mr Whaley, who spent his last night having dinner with his family at a hotel in Zurich, replied: Ann can handle anything. The one thing that has worried me all along is leaving Ann because Ive spent all my le protecting her. Now shell be without me, but I know shell get through it. Mr Whaleys letter to MPs in full: Dear Members of Parliament, By the time you read this, I will be dead. On Thursday th February , I will have taken medication that will end my le, surrounded by my we, Ann, my children, Alix and Dominic, and a couple of my dearest friends at the Dignitas facility in Switzerland. With their love and support I have been able to fulfil my final wish: to be in control of my end, rather than endure the immense suffering motor neurone disease had in store for me. I want to impress upon you the anguish me and my family have experienced, not because of this awful illness , but because of the law against assisted dying in this country. The blanket ban on assisted dying has not only forced me to spend thousands of pounds and endure months of logistical hurdles in order to secure a peaceful and dignied death overseas, but it has meant that my final weeks of le have been blighted by visits from social services and police. Since my diagnosis of MND, an incurable, terminal illness, in , I felt as though bombs have been dropping on me. I gradually lost the use of all four limbs. My ability to speak, swallow and breathe began rapidly deteriorating. I knew my death was inevitable and unavoidable, but I remained strong for my family. I am  years old and have lived a full le. I did not fear death, but I did fear the journey. I simply wanted to cut this suffering short by a few months. When I eventually got the ‘green light’ from Dignitas, a weight lted I was able to get on with living without the constant mental anguish over my death. But then, as I was saying my final goodbyes and preparing myself for the end, the final, biggest bomb dropped and I could no longer keep it together. This bomb was in fact an anonymous phone call to social services who informed the police of my plans to go to Switzerland. Within hours Ann and I were facing a criminal investigation. The thought that I might not make it to Switzerland, or that,I did, Ann might be facing  years in jail for helping me, was almost too much to bear. In  years of marriage, Ann had not seen me cry. The day we were contacted by the police, I sobbed. The law in this country robbed me of control over my death. It forced me to seek solace in Switzerland. Then it sought to punish those attempting to help me get there. The hypocrisy and cruelty of this is astounding. Though it is perfectly legal for me make arrangements and travel to Dignitas by myself, the minute anyone  ‘assists’ me in any way – which is essential, due to my condition – they are liable for prosecution. I had the chance, just over a week before my death, to speak to some MPs and Peers about my experience and my adamant wish that the law should be changed. The overwhelming reaction in the room was one of agreement however, I am aware that despite huge public support for an assisted dying law, most members of parliament currently oppose it. I spoke to one MP who had voted against the last assisted dying Bill in . The law being proposed was limited to terminally ill, mentally competent adults in their final months, with strict inbuilt safeguards to protect the vulnerable and anyone  who has not made a clear decision of their own volition. When I pressed her on why she felt people like me should be denied a say over our own death and be forced to suffer, she was unable to articulate an answer. I want MPs to know that change is urgently needed and that it is achievable – over  million people in several American and Australian states and across Canada are covered by assisted dying laws which allow choice to dying people and protection to others. No family should ever have to endure the torment we have undergone in recent weeks, but it will be easier to bear knowing that by sharing it we can contribute to future change. I sincerely hope that you will truly listen to our story and see the suffering you are inflicting by upholding the status quo. Yours sincerely, Geoffrey Whaley

story: NewsGirl, , SCALPED when ponytail got tangled in her uncles tractor in freak accidentWARNING - EXTREMELY GRAPHIC CONTENT: Khushpreet Kaurs forehead was successfully reattached after the freak accidentShareCommentsByJack Longstaff:,  FEB NewsKhushpreet Kaur had her forehead reattached by doctors and her hair is starting to grow back "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A young girl whose forehead was ripped off after her ponytail got tangled in her uncles tractor has undergone major surgery to have it reattached. Nine-year-old Khushpreet Kaur was left screaming in agony in the freak accident that tore off large parts of her scalp. The youngsters head was torn apart by a tractors crop spraying machine in rural India .She was sitting on top of her uncles tractor, when her dress got caught, dragging her helplessly towards the machinery. Her dress became tangled up in the spinning sprayer, which led to her hair getting caught and wound around its rotating parts. Her hair was pulled clean from her head.   The horric ordeal happened on November  last year when Khushpreet was riding on top of her uncles tractor in Dharampura village in Punjab, India. He was watering a field of orange orchards when he discovered his niece covered in blood and missing half her scalp. She was rushed to hospital km away in Bathinda, where surgeons performed an eight hour long operation to reattach her forehead and scalp.   Aspiring school teacher, Khushpreet, spent  days recovering in intensive care at the Cosmo Superspeciality Hospital following the operation. She has now fully recovered and her hair is beginning to grow back. Lead cosmetic surgeon, Dr Raman Goyal, says he had to cancel other operations to prioritise Khushpreets urgent medical emergency.   He said: Khushpreets complete scalp and the skin of her forehead had peeled off in the accident. As soon as she was brought in we decided to conduct micro vascular repair of the scalp and reattach the same. The complex surgery lasted for about eight hours. He added that this type of scalp re-plant was one of the rare plastic surgeries to be conducted in the country. Surjeet Singh, Khushpreets father has thanked medics for giving his daughter a new lease of le.

title: my sweet 14 year olds
story: NewsMy sweet -year-old daughters "baby bump" ended up killing herMum Ange Ienco began imagining the worst when she felt her daughter Giovannas stomach and found a "five-month baby bump"ShareCommentsBySophie Evans:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news world-news video baby-bump-ends-up-killing-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhen mum Ange Ienco was asked whether her -year-old daughter was pregnant during netball training, she was outraged. Her sweet Giovanna had always had a small pot belly, but watching her train, she could see her stomach was clearly jutting out. And later, when feeling the schoolgirls protruding stomach, she was shocked to find what appeared to be a five-month baby bump. I fretted, imagining the worst, Ange recalled. With her daughters stomach rock hard, she began asking herself terrying questions, like whether the teen could have been assaulted. But it would later turn out that Giovanna wasnt expecting. Instead, she had silent killer oian cancer - with the mystery bump actually a football-sized tumour on her oy.And in July , despite gruelling chemotherapy, Giovanna peacefully passed away, surrounded by her heartbroken family. The courageous teen had only recently turned . Our daughter is the bravest, strongest, most beautul person I ever knew, Ange, from Merbein, Australia, toldtoday. And I am so proud and honoured that she chose me to be her mum. In a message to other parents, she added: Always talk with your children about their health and being aware of changes in their body.  Have the dialogue open and teach them that they can advocate for their health. Education is key in our children learning more about their bodies as well as silent illnesses that can arise. Bubbly Giovanna, known affectionately as G, had been taking part in netball training when her coach approached her mum. She asked her, Is Giovanna pregnant , leaving her furious.In a beautul letter to her daughter, published on Kidspot , Ange recalls: What the hell  She’s only a kid! I fumed inwardly.But that night, the mum gently asked her daughter whether she could feel her stomach - and discovered the apparent baby bump. Putting my hands on your stomach, it felt like a five-month baby bump and hard as a rock, she writes in the letter.  The following day, Giovanna was taken to the doctors, where she did a pregnancy test before being rushed for an ultrasound. The scan revealed her enormous growth. And later, after undergoing surgery to remove her -kilo tumour, the brave teenager was diagnosed with oian cancer. They removed her oy along with a kg tumour, Ange told us. Giovanna recovered in hospital for the next five days. By this time disbelief had worn off and we were all upbeat about going home, and of course Giovanna was over the moon with her now new figure and flat tummy. [But on] May , , we were rushed down to Melbourne to be told Giovanna had oian cancer. The schoolgirl, who had undergone the operation at Victorias Royal Childrens Hospital, subsequently underwent chemotherapy.  She had her first round of treatment on her th birthday. While her main concern was the thought of losing her hair, her mum feared that she may not be able to have children in the future. Little did we know this was not our main concern, Ange said. She added: All she wanted for her birthday was a party with all her friends, so two weeks after her chemo  of her best friends joined her in celebrating her th birthday. She said afterwards that it was the best night of her le. I am so glad and thankful that we did this, it is even more special now as it was to be her last birthday. Giovanna, who had also been suffering from tiredness before her diagnosis, was rushed back to hospital at the end of May .  She was in agonising pain, with her stomach growing once again. And this time, it swelled to the size of a nine-month baby bump. I even had to buy you a pair of size- pyjama pants, Ange, who also has a son, Nando, writes in her touching letter to her daughter. After spending a week at Royal Childrens Hospital, Giovanna was transferred to the Royal Womens Hospital in Parkville, Melbourne. Despite medics best efforts, her organs began shutting down and she was sedated to ease her pain, as her family stayed beside her. And at .pm on July , the schoolgirl lost her courageous battle, as her distraught mum sobbed: Go darling, fly with the angels. Her final, selfless wish was for her family to raise money to fund Ronald McDonald Houses, which provide a home away from home for seriously ill children and their loved ones.   Today, Ange and her husband Fred are living every persons worst nightmare, suffering from a dull ache that is constantly present.But in honour of their beloved daughter, they have set up Giovannas Gt , a charity which raises awareness and money for oian cancer research and Ronald McDonald Houses.The couple, who are determined to make sure no-one  has to walk in their shoes, fund a room at the Ronald McDonald House in Parkville in memory of Giovanna. And they also raise much-needed funds for teenagers with cancer who at times are the forgotten ones when it comes to gts and items of need.   They are desperate to spare other families the same pain they are going through. Oian cancer, the silent killer, is not so well known as its cousin, breast cancer, yet can be far more dangerous, Ange said. Oian cancer is one of the most common types of cancer among women, but its symptoms can be dficult to recognise.According to the NHS , they include a swollen stomach, feeling constantly bloated, stomach or pelvic discomfort, feeling full quickly when eating, and needing to urinate more often than normal. For more information on Giovannas Gt, you can visit the charitys Facebook page here or website here
